question: Question_06_(f)
statement:
Suppose you expanded the same function \emph{$f$(x) = x} as in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} except on the interval $0 \leq x \leq 2$. What would be the
\emph{form} (i.e., do not compute the coefficients) of the Fourier
series valid for this interval? What points on the plane would you plot
to produce a frequency-amplitude plot from this new Fourier series?
(Give the answer in terms of the coefficients in the new expansion.)
sols:
If we extend the domain from $[0,1]$ to $[0,2]$, we can write the new
Fourier coefficients $d_n$ using the techniques from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} as

\begin{align*}d_n=\frac{1}{2}\int_0^2xe^{-2\pi{}inx/2}\textrm{d}x.\end{align*}

We could go and directly compute these integrals but we want to relate
them to the coefficients $c_n$ from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} computed on a domain $[0,1]$. To do this, we can use a substitution
and let $u=\frac{x}{2}$. Then $\displaystyle {}dx=2du$. With this
transformation we have $u(0)=0$ and $u(2)=1$ and so putting everything
together,

\begin{align*}d_n=2\int_0^1ue^{-2\pi{}inu}\textrm{d}u=2c_n\end{align*}

where we have recognized that the new integral is precisely what we
computed to get the coefficients on a period $[0,1]$. Therefore on
$[0,2]$ the Fourier coefficients double and

\begin{align*}d_n=\begin{cases}
2\frac{1}{2}=1,\qquad{}n=0\\
2\frac{i}{2\pi{}n}=\frac{i}{\pi{}n},\qquad{}n\neq0
\end{cases}.\end{align*}

Therefore we have that $\displaystyle {}|d_n|=2|c_n|$ and the points to
plot for the frequency amplitude are $\displaystyle {}(n,2|c_n|)$.
hints:
The Fourier coefficients to the function $x$ over an interval $[0,L]$
are given by

\begin{align*}c_n=\frac{1}{L}\int_0^Lxe^{-2\pi{}inx/L}\textrm{d}x.\end{align*}

How can we transform these integrals to be over $[0,1]$ instead?
